title: Exempt homes hit by new O'Hare noise from property tax hike, group urges
text:
Chicagoans inundated with new O’Hare International Airport jet noise should not have to shoulder the record property tax increase proposed by Mayor Rahm Emanuel, the leader of a citizen group said Friday.
As a result, the Fair Allocation in Runways coalition wants members to urge their aldermen to vote down the Emanuel budget containing $588 million in property tax increases over four years unless steps are taken to fix the city’s “flawed” $8.7 billion O’Hare overhaul plan, said Colleen Mulcrone of FAIR.
Emanuel has contended that without the massive property tax increase, the city would have to cut so many services it would become “unlivable,” Mulcrone told the O’Hare Noise Compatibility Commission Friday.
But life in Chicago for those under new flight paths has been “unlivable” for the last two years, Mulcrone said — ever since O’Hare directed 70 percent of all arriving jets over Chicago homes.
“Asking us to pay more,” Mulcrone said, is “unfair” and “insulting.” She noted that some Chicago owners of jet-noise-impacted homes already have had their properties reassessed upward by 20 to 30 percent.
“Everybody says, ‘How can you raise our taxes this much when we are getting 360 flights over our heads [a day]?’” Mulcrone said.
FAIR contends aldermen of affected wards — the 41st, 39th, 40th, 45th and 38th — should vote down the budget and its property tax increase unless the city and Chicago Department of Aviation agree to spare two diagonal runways scheduled for demolition and use them to spread out air traffic more evenly across the city and suburbs. The group also urges a moratorium on future runway work.
Residents east and west of the airport have been deluged with new jet noise ever since O’Hare dramatically changed its flight paths in October 2013. Last year O’Hare racked up the most jet noise complaints among the nation’s 10 busiest airports — by a landslide, a Chicago Sun-Times/Better Government Association investigation found.
The switch in flight paths is part of an ongoing O’Hare shift from dependence on mostly diagonal runways aimed at suburbs north and south of airport to what the city says is a more efficient network of mostly parallel east-west runways.
Mulcrone also pointed to a new software tool outlined Friday by Federal Aviation Administration officials that helps air traffic controllers avoid traffic safety issues when a certain diagonal runway — 14R/32L — is used at O’Hare. She questioned why the diagonal had to be decommissioned in 2020 if its safety concerns had now been addressed.
However, FAA spokesman Tony Molinaro said the new tool merely allows the FAA to “add a small number of flights in a safe way.” City aviation officials insist the diagonal, if kept, would create more safety problems with another runway and runway extension planned on the north end of the airfield by 2021 and would interfere with a planned western access route into O’Hare.
A cargo plane is shown taking off from O’Hare’s new runway 10C-28C in October 2013. | Brian O’Mahoney/For Sun-Times Media
